verses.latin: Paulus autem, cum Athenis eos exspectaret, incitabatur spiritus ejus in ipso, videns idololatriae deditam civitatem.
verses.english: Now while Paul was waiting for them in Athens, his spirit was provoked within him as he saw that the city was full of idols.

verses.latin: Cotidie ergo disputabat in synagoga cum Judaeis, et colentibus, et in foro per omnem diem cum qui aderant.
verses.english: So he reasoned in the synagogue with the Jews and the devout persons, and in the marketplace every day with those who happened to be there.

verses.latin: Quidam autem epicurei et stoici philosophi, concurrebant ad eum: et quidam dicebant: Quid vult seminiverbius hic dicere? Alii: Novorum daemoniorum videtur esse praedicator: quia Jesum et resurrectionem annuntiabat eis.
verses.english: Some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers also debated with him. Some said, "What does this babbler want to say?" Others said, "He seems to be a preacher of foreign divinities," because he was preaching about Jesus and the resurrection.

verses.latin: Et adprehendentes eum, ad Areopagum duxerunt, dicentes: Possumus scire quae est haec nova doctrina, quae a te dicitur?
verses.english: And they took him and brought him to the Areopagus, saying, "May we know what this new teaching is that you are presenting?

verses.latin: nova enim quaedam infers auribus nostris: volumus ergo scire quid velint haec esse.
verses.english: For you bring some strange things to our ears. We want to know therefore what these things mean."

verses.latin: (Athenienses autem omnes, et advenae hospites, ad nihil aliud vacabant, nisi dicere, aut audire aliquid novi).
verses.english: Now all the Athenians and the foreigners who lived there would spend their time in nothing except telling or hearing something new.

verses.latin: Stans autem Paulus in medio Areopagi, ait: Viri Athenienses, per omnia quasi religiosiores vos video.
verses.english: So Paul, standing in the midst of the Areopagus, said, "Men of Athens, I perceive that in all things you are very religious.

verses.latin: Praeteriens enim et videns simulacra vestra, inveni et aram, in qua scriptum erat: Ignoto Deo. Quod ergo ignorantes colitis, hoc ego vobis annuntio.
verses.english: For as I passed along and observed the objects of your worship, I found also an altar with this inscription, 'To the unknown god.' What therefore you worship as unknown, this I proclaim to you.

verses.latin: Deus, qui fecit mundum, et omnia quae in eo sunt, hic caelii et terrae Dominus existens, non in manufactis templis habitat,
verses.english: The God who made the world and everything in it, being Lord of the universe and the earth, does not live in temples made by hands,

verses.latin: neque manibus colitur, indigens aliquid, ipse dans omnibus vitam, et inspirationem, et omnia:
verses.english: nor is he served by human hands, as though he needed anything, since he himself gives to all mankind life and breath and everything.

verses.latin: fecitque ex uno omne genus hominum habitare super universam faciem terrae, definiens statuta tempora, et terminos habitationis eorum,
verses.english: And he made from one man every nation of mankind to live on all the face of the earth, having determined allotted periods and the boundaries of their dwelling place,

verses.latin: quaerere Deum si forte attrectent eum, aut inveniant, quamvis non longe sit ab unoquoque nostrum.
verses.english: that they should seek God, and perhaps feel their way toward him and find him. Yet he is actually not far from each one of us,

verses.latin: In ipso enim vivimus, et movemur, et sumus: sicut et quidam ex vestris poëtis dixerunt: Ipsius enim genus sumus.
verses.english: for "'In him we live and move and have our being'; as even some of your own poets have said, 'For we are indeed his offspring.'

verses.latin: Genus igitur cum simus Dei, non debemus putare auro, aut argento, aut lapidi, sculpturae artis, et cogitationis hominis, simile esse divinum.
verses.english: Being then God's offspring, we ought not to think that the divine being is like gold or silver or stone, an image formed by the art and imagination of man.

verses.latin: Tempora igitur ignorantiæ despiciens Deus, nunc annuntiat hominibus ut omnes ubique pœnitentiam agant,
verses.english: The times of ignorance therefore God overlooked, but now he commands all people everywhere to repent,

verses.latin: eo quod statuit diem, in quo judicaturus est orbem in justitia in viro, quem constituit, fidem præbens omnibus, suscitans eum a mortuis.
verses.english: because he has fixed a day on which he will judge the world in righteousness by a man whom he has appointed; and of this he has given assurance to all by raising him from the dead."

verses.latin: Cum audissent autem resurrectionem mortuorum, quidam quidem irridebant: quidam vero dixerunt: Iterum te audiemus super hac re.
verses.english: Now when they heard of the resurrection of the dead, some mocked. But others said, "We will hear you again about this."

verses.latin: Sic Paulus exivit de medio eorum.
verses.english: So Paul went out from their midst.

verses.latin: Quidam vero viri adhaeserunt ei, et crediderunt: in quibus et Dionysius Areopagita, et Damaris, et ceteri cum eis.
verses.english: But some men joined him and believed, among whom also were Dionysius the Areopagite and a woman named Damaris and others with them.

verses.latin: Post haec, egressus ab Athenis, venit Corinthum.
verses.english: After these things, Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.

verses.latin: Et cum invenisset quemdam Judaeum, nomine Aquilam, genere Ponticum, qui nuper venerat ab Italia, et Priscillam uxorem ejus (eo quod praecepisset Caesar omnes Judaeos discedere a Roma), accessit ad eos.
verses.english: And when he found a certain Jew named Aquila, a native of Pontus, who had recently come from Italy, and Priscilla his wife (because Claudius had ordered all Jews to depart from Rome), he went to them.

verses.latin: Et, quia ejusdem erat artis, manebat apud eos, et operabatur. Erat enim coriorum artifex.
verses.english: And because he practiced the same trade, he stayed with them and worked; for they were tentmakers.

verses.latin: Et disputabat in synagoga per omne sabbatum, interponens nomen Domini Jesu, et suadebat Judaeis et Graecis.
verses.english: And he reasoned in the synagogue every Sabbath, explaining the name of Jesus, and persuading Jews and Greeks.

verses.latin: Cum autem descendissent de Macedonia et Silas et Timotheus, instabat verbo Paulus, testificans Judaeis Christum Jesum.
verses.english: But when Silas and Timothy came down from Macedonia, Paul was pressed by the word, testifying to the Jews that Jesus was the Christ.

verses.latin: Contradicentibus autem eis et blasphemantibus, excutiens vestimenta, dixit ad eos: Sanguis vester super caput vestrum: mundus ego: ex hoc, ibo ad gentes.
verses.english: But when they opposed and blasphemed, he shook his garments and said to them: “Your blood be upon your own heads; I am clean. From now on I will go to the Gentiles.”

verses.latin: Et egressus inde, venit in domum cujusdam justi, nomine Titi Justi, adjacentis synagogae.
verses.english: And he departed from there and went to the house of a certain man named Titus Justus, a worshiper of God, whose house was next door to the synagogue.

verses.latin: Et Crispus, princeps synagogae, credidit Domino cum omni domo sua: et multi Corinthiorum audientes credebant, et baptizabantur.
verses.english: And Crispus, the ruler of the synagogue, believed in the Lord with all his house. And many of the Corinthians hearing, believed and were baptized.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Dominus in visione nocte Paulo: Noli timere, sed loquere, et ne taceas:
verses.english: And the Lord said to Paul in the night by a vision: “Do not be afraid, but speak and do not keep silent;

verses.latin: quia ego sum tecum: et nemo irruet super te, ut noceat tibi: quoniam populus est mihi multus in hac civitate.
verses.english: for I am with you, and no one will attack you to harm you, for I have many people in this city.”

verses.latin: Sedit autem ibi annum et sex menses, docens in illis verbum Dei.
verses.english: And he stayed there a year and six months, teaching the word of God among them.

verses.latin: Porro cum Gallio proconsul esset Achaiae, insurrexerunt uno animo Judaei in Paulum, et adduxerunt eum ad tribunal,
verses.english: But when Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews with one accord rose up against Paul and brought him to the judgment seat,

verses.latin: dicentes: Quia hic persuadet homines colere Deum contra legem.
verses.english: saying: “This fellow persuades men to worship God contrary to the law.”

verses.latin: Cum autem coepisset Paulus aperire os, dixit Gallio ad Judaeos: Si quidem esset iniquum aliquid aut scelus pessimum, o Judaei, recte vos sustinerem.
verses.english: And when Paul was about to open his mouth, Gallio said to the Jews: “If there were any act of wrongdoing or a wicked crime, O Jews, I would have reason to hear you.

verses.latin: Si vero quaestiones sunt de verbo et nominibus et lege vestra, vos ipsi videritis: judex ego horum nolo esse.
verses.english: But if there are questions of words and names and your law, you yourselves look to it. I will not be a judge of these things.”

verses.latin: Et minavit eos a tribunali.
verses.english: And he drove them from the judgment seat.

verses.latin: Tunc omnes apprehenderunt Sosthenem principem synagogae, et percutiebant eum ante tribunal: et nihil eorum Gallioni curae erat.
verses.english: Then all the Greeks seized Sosthenes, the ruler of the synagogue, and beat him before the judgment seat. But Gallio was not concerned about any of these things.

verses.latin: Paulus vero, cum adhuc sustinuisset dies multos, valedixit fratribus, et navigaverat in Syriam (et cum eo Priscilla et Aquila), qui totonderat in Cenchris caput: votum enim habebat.
verses.english: Then Paul, after staying many more days, took leave of the brothers and sailed away to Syria, and with him Priscilla and Aquila, having cut his hair in Cenchreae; for he had a vow.

verses.latin: Descenditque Ephesum: et illic reliquit eos. Ipse vero ingressus synagogam, disputabat cum Judaeis.
verses.english: And he came to Ephesus, and he left them there. But he himself entered the synagogue and reasoned with the Jews.

verses.latin: Rogantibus autem eis ut amplius maneret, non consensit:
verses.english: When they asked him to stay longer, he did not consent,

verses.latin: sed valedixit eis, dicens: Iterum revertar ad vos, Deo volente. Et profectus est ab Epheso.
verses.english: but took leave of them, saying: “I must by all means keep this coming feast in Jerusalem. But I will return again to you, God willing.” And he set out from Ephesus.

verses.latin: Et descendens Cesaream, ascendit et salutavit ecclesiam, et deinde descendit Antiochiam.
verses.english: And when he had come down to Caesarea, he went up and greeted the church, and then he went down to Antioch.

verses.latin: Et facto ibi aliquanto tempore, profectus est perambulans ex ordine Galaticam regionem et Phrygiam, confirmans omnes discipulos.
verses.english: And having spent some time there, he departed and went through the region of Galatia and Phrygia in order, strengthening all the disciples.

verses.latin: Judaeus autem quidam, Apollo nomine, Alexandrinus genere, vir eloquens, pervenit Ephesum, potens in scripturis.
verses.english: Now a certain Jew named Apollos, an Alexandrian by birth, an eloquent man, came to Ephesus, mighty in the Scriptures.

verses.latin: Hic erat edoctus viam Domini: et ferens fervens spiritu, loquebatur et docebat diligenter ea quae sunt Jesu, sciens tantum baptisma Joannis.
verses.english: This man was instructed in the way of the Lord, and being fervent in spirit, he spoke and taught accurately the things concerning Jesus, knowing only the baptism of John.

verses.latin: Hic coepit fiducialiter agere in synagoga. Quem cum audissent Priscilla et Aquila, assumpserunt eum, et diligentius expoderunt ei viam Domini.
verses.english: And he began to speak boldly in the synagogue. But when Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they took him and explained to him the way of God more accurately.

verses.latin: Cum autem voluit ire Achaian, hortati sunt fratres scribentes discipulis, ut susciperent eum. Qui cum venisset, contulit multum his qui crediderant:
verses.english: And when he wanted to pass over to Achaia, the brothers wrote, exhorting the disciples to receive him. When he arrived, he greatly helped those who had believed,

verses.latin: vehementer enim arguebat Judaeos publice, ostendens per Scripturas, Christum Jesum esse.
verses.english: for he vigorously refuted the Jews publicly, showing by the Scriptures that Jesus is the Christ.

verses.latin: Factum est autem cum Apollo esset Corinthi, Paulum peragrassentem superiora partes, venit Ephesum, et inveniens quosdam discipulos,
verses.english: After Apollos had moved on to Corinth, Paul traveled through the upper regions and came to Ephesus. There, he found some disciples,

verses.latin: dixit ad eos: Si Spiritum Sanctum accepistis credentes? At illi dixerunt ad eum: Sed neque si Spiritus Sanctus est, audivimus.
verses.english: and he said to them, “Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed?” They replied, “We haven’t even heard that there is a Holy Spirit.”

verses.latin: Ait illis: In quo ergo baptizati estis? Qui dixerunt: In Ioannis baptismate.
verses.english: He asked them, “Then how were you baptized?” They answered, “With John's baptism.”

verses.latin: Dixit autem Paulus: Ioannes baptizavit baptismum paenitentiae populo, dicens: In eum, qui post se venturus erat, ut crederent, hoc est, in Jesum.
verses.english: Paul then said, “John baptized with a baptism of repentance, telling the people to believe in the one who was to come after him, that is, Jesus.”

verses.latin: His auditis, baptizati sunt in nomine Domini Jesu.
verses.english: After hearing this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.

verses.latin: Et cum imposuisset eis manus Paulus, venit Spiritus Sanctus in eos, et loquebantur linguis, et prophetabant.
verses.english: And when Paul laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came upon them, and they began speaking in tongues and prophesying.

verses.latin: Erant autem simul viros circiter duodecim.
verses.english: There were about twelve men in all.

verses.latin: Introgressus autem synagogam, cum fiducia loquebatur per tres menses, disputans et suadens de regno Dei.
verses.english: He entered the synagogue, and for three months he spoke boldly, debating and persuading people about the kingdom of God.

verses.latin: Cum autem quidam indurarentur, et non crederent, maledicentes viam Domini coram multitudine, recedens ab eis, separavit discipulos, quotidie disputans in schola Tyranni.
verses.english: But when some of them hardened themselves and refused to believe, speaking evil of the Way before the crowd, he left them, and separated the disciples, arguing daily in the school of Tyrannus.

verses.latin: Hoc autem factum est per biennium, ita ut omnes qui habitabant in Asia, audirent verbum Domini Jesu, tam Judaei quam gentiles.
verses.english: This continued for two years, so that all the inhabitants of Asia heard the word of the Lord Jesus, both Jews and Greeks.

verses.latin: Virtutes autem non quaslibet faciebat Deus per manus Pauli,
verses.english: And God worked extraordinary miracles by the hands of Paul,

verses.latin: ita ut super languidos deferrentur a corpore ejus sudaria, vel semicinctia, et recedebant ab eis languores, et spiritus nequam egrediebantur.
verses.english: so that when they placed handkerchiefs or aprons that had touched his body on the sick, their diseases left them, and the evil spirits came out of them.

verses.latin: Yersi autem quidam ex circumcursantibus Judaeis exorcistis, tentaverunt invocare super eos, qui habebant spiritus malos, nomen Domini Jesu, dicentes: Adjuro vos per Jesum, quem Paulus praedicat.
verses.english: Then some itinerant Jewish exorcists tried to invoke the name of the Lord Jesus over those who had evil spirits, saying, “I adjure you by the Jesus whom Paul preaches.”

verses.latin: Erant autem quidam Judaei, septem filii Scævæ principis sacerdotum, qui hoc faciebant.
verses.english: There were seven sons of a Jewish high priest named Sceva who were doing this.

verses.latin: Respondens autem spiritus malus, dixit eis: Jesum scio, et Paulum scio: vos autem qui estis?
verses.english: But the evil spirit answered them, “Jesus I know, and Paul I know, but who are you?”

verses.latin: Et insiliens in eos homo, in quo erat spiritus nequam, et dominatus amborum, invaluit contra eos, ita ut nudi et vulnerati effugerent de domo illa.
verses.english: And the man with the evil spirit leaped on them, overpowered them all, and they ran out of the house naked and wounded.

verses.latin: Hoc autem notum factum est omnibus, tam Judæis quam gentilibus, qui habitabant Ephesi: et cecidit timor super omnes, et magnificabatur nomen Domini Jesu.
verses.english: This became known to everyone in Ephesus, both Jews and Greeks. Fear fell on them all, and the name of the Lord Jesus was magnified.

verses.latin: Multique credentium veniebant, confitentes et annuntiantes actus suos.
verses.english: Many of those who had believed came, confessing and divulging their practices.

verses.latin: Multi autem ex eis, qui fuerant curiosa sectati, contulerunt libros suos, et combusserunt coram omnibus: et computata sunt pretia illorum, et inventa sunt denariorum quinquaginta milia.
verses.english: And a number of those who had practiced magic arts brought their books together and burned them in front of everyone. When they calculated the value of the books, they found that it came to fifty thousand pieces of silver.

verses.latin: Ita potenter verbum Dei crescebat, et confirmabatur.
verses.english: So the word of the Lord continued to grow and prevail.

verses.latin: His autem finitis, proposuit Paulus in Spiritu, cum pertransisset Macedoniam et Achaiam, ire Jerosolymam, dicens: Quoniam postquam fuero ibi, oportet me et Romam videre.
verses.english: Now after these events, Paul decided in the Spirit to go through Macedonia and Achaia and then to go to Jerusalem, saying, “After I have been there, I must also see Rome.”

verses.latin: Mittens autem in Macedoniam duos ex ministrantibus sibi, Timotheum et Erastum, ipse remansit per modicum tempus in Asia.
verses.english: So he sent two of his assistants, Timothy and Erastus, to Macedonia, while he himself stayed in Asia for a while.

verses.latin: Facta est autem illo tempore turbatio non minima de via Domini.
verses.english: About that time, there arose a considerable disturbance concerning the Way.

verses.latin: Demetrius enim quidam, argentarius, faciens ædificia argentea Dianæ, præstabant artificibus non minimum quaestum:
verses.english: For a man named Demetrius, a silversmith, who made silver shrines of Artemis, was bringing no little business to the artisans.

verses.latin: quos congregans cum his, qui talia faciebant, dixit: Viri, scitis quia de hoc artificio est nobis acquisitio:
verses.english: He gathered them together with the workmen of similar trades and said, “Men, you know that our prosperity depends on this business.

verses.latin: et videtis et auditis quod non solum Ephesi, sed pene totius Asiæ Paulus hic, convertit multam turbam, dicens, quia non sunt dii, qui manibus fiunt.
verses.english: You also see and hear that not only in Ephesus but in almost the whole of Asia, this Paul has persuaded and turned away a great many people, saying that gods made with hands are not gods.

verses.latin: Non solum autem hoc periclitabitur nobis pars, ut in nihilum veniat rationis, sed et magnæ Dianæ templum æstimabitur pro nihilo, et incipiet destrui magnitudo ejus, quam tota Asia, et orbis colit.
verses.english: And there is danger not only that this trade of ours may be discredited, but also that the temple of the great goddess Artemis may be counted as nothing, and that she whom all of Asia and the world worship will be dethroned from her magnificence.”

verses.latin: His auditis, et pleni iræ facti, clamabant dicentes: Magna Diana Ephesiorum.
verses.english: When they heard this, they were enraged and began crying out, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”

verses.latin: Et impleta est civitas confusione, et irruerunt uno animo in theatrum, rapta Gayo et Aristarcho Macedonibus, Pauli comitibus.
verses.english: The city was filled with confusion, and they rushed together into the theater, dragging along Gaius and Aristarchus, Paul's Macedonian travel companions.

verses.latin: Paulo autem volente intrare in populum, non permiserunt discipuli.
verses.english: But when Paul wanted to go in among the crowd, the disciples would not let him.

verses.latin: Sed et quidam de Asia principum, cum essent amici ejus, miserunt ad eum rogantes ne se daret in theatrum.
verses.english: Some of the Asiarchs, who were friends of his, also sent a message to him urging him not to venture into the theater.

verses.latin: Alii quidem aliud clamabant: erat enim concio confusa, et plures nesciebant cujus causa convenissent.
verses.english: Now some cried out one thing, some another, for the assembly was in confusion, and most of them did not know why they had come together.

verses.latin: De turba autem detraxerunt Alexandrum, propellentibus eum Judæis. Alexander autem, manu agitans, voluit rationem reddere plebi.
verses.english: Some of the crowd prompted Alexander, whom the Jews had put forward. And Alexander, motioning with his hand, wanted to make a defense to the crowd.

verses.latin: Cognoscentes autem quod Judæus esset, una vox facta est omnium, per duas horas clamantes: Magna Diana Ephesiorum.
verses.english: But when they recognized that he was a Jew, for about two hours they all with one voice cried out, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”

verses.latin: Et cum sedasset scriba plebem, dixit: Viri Ephesii, quis enim est homo qui nesciat Ephesiorum civitatem cultricem esse magnæ Dianæ, et simulacri ab Jove prolapsi?
verses.english: And when the town clerk had quieted the crowd, he said, “Men of Ephesus, who is there who does not know that the city of the Ephesians is a worshiper of the great Artemis and of the image that fell from heaven?

verses.latin: Cum ergo his contradici non possit, oportet vos sedatos esse, et nihil temere agere.
verses.english: Since these things cannot be denied, you ought to be quiet and do nothing rash.

verses.latin: Adduxistis enim homines istos, neque sacrilegos, neque blasphemantes Deam vestram.
verses.english: For you have brought these men here who are neither sacrilegious nor blasphemers of our goddess.

verses.latin: Quod si Demetrius, et qui cum eo sunt artifices, habent adversus aliquem causam, conventus forenses aguntur, et proconsules sunt: accusent invicem.
verses.english: If therefore Demetrius and the craftsmen with him have a complaint against anyone, the courts are open, and there are proconsuls; let them bring charges against one another.

verses.latin: Si quid autem ultra de his quæritis, in legitima concione poterit iudicari.
verses.english: But if you want anything further, it shall be settled in the regular assembly.

verses.latin: Nam et periclitamur seditionis accusari pro hac die, cum nullus obnoxius sit de his, per quos concurritis.
verses.english: For we are in danger of being charged with rioting today, since there is no cause for which we can give an account of this commotion.”

verses.latin: Et cum hæc dixisset, dimisit concionem.
verses.english: And when he had said these things, he dismissed the assembly.

verses.latin: Et postquam cessavit tumultus, evocatis Paulus discipulis, et exhortatus eos, profectus est ut iret in Macedoniam.
verses.english: After the riot had ended, Paul called together his disciples, and encouraged them. Then he departed, heading towards Macedonia.

verses.latin: Cumque per eas partes ambulasset, et exhortatus verbo multo eos, venit in Graeciam:
verses.english: Having traveled throughout those areas, he encouraged them with many words. Then he came to Greece.

verses.latin: ubi facto mense, facto ei sunt insidiæ a Judæis, navigaturus in Syriam: ratus est ergo remeare per Macedoniam.
verses.english: He spent three months there. When the Jews plotted against him, intending to sail to Syria, he decided to return through Macedonia.

verses.latin: Comitabantur autem eum Sopatros Pyrrhi Bereensis, Thessalonicensium vero Aristarchus, et Secundus, et Gaius Derbeus, et Timotheus: Tychicus autem, et Trophimus, Asiani.
verses.english: Sopater, son of Pyrrhus, from Berea, Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica, Gaius from Derbe, and Timothy accompanied him. Tychicus and Trophimus from Asia were also with him.

verses.latin: Hi præcedentes, sustinuerunt nos Troadem.
verses.english: These men went ahead and waited for us in Troas.

verses.latin: Nos vero navigavimus post dies Azymorum a Philippis, et venimus ad eos Troadem, in quo mansimus diebus quinque.
verses.english: After the Feast of Unleavened Bread, we sailed from Philippi. Five days later, we met them in Troas.

verses.latin: In una autem sabbati, cum convenissent discipuli ad frangendum panem, Paulus disputabat eis, profecturus in crastinum: protulitque sermonem usque in mediam noctem.
verses.english: On the first day of the week, when the disciples gathered to break bread, Paul spoke with them, since he was going to leave the next day. He kept speaking until midnight.

verses.latin: Erant autem lampades multæ in cœnaculo, ubi eramus congregati.
verses.english: There were many lamps in the upper room where we were gathered.

verses.latin: Sedens autem quidam adolescens, nomine Eutychus, in fenestra, oppressus somno gravi, disputante Paulo prolixius, evigilans, decidit de tertio cœnaculo deorsum: et sublatus est mortuus.
verses.english: A young man named Eutychus was sitting in a window. He was overcome by deep sleep while Paul was speaking at length, and falling from the third story, he was taken up dead.

verses.latin: Descendens autem Paulus, incubuit super eum, et amplexatus eum, dixit: Nolite turbari, anima enim ejus in ipso est.
verses.english: Paul went down and threw himself on him. Embracing him, he said, “Do not be alarmed, for his soul is in him.”

verses.latin: Ascendens autem, et frangens panem, et gustans, sat multo locutus est usque in lucem: et ita profectus est.
verses.english: Then he went upstairs, broke bread, and ate. He talked for a long time until dawn. Then he departed.

verses.latin: Adduxerunt autem puerum viventem, et consolati sunt non minime.
verses.english: They took the young man back alive, and they were greatly comforted.

verses.latin: Nos autem ascendentes in navem, et navigantes venimus contra Assonem, inde suscepturi Paulum: sic enim statuerat, ipse venturus per terram.
verses.english: Meanwhile, we went ahead to the ship and sailed to Assos, where we were going to take Paul aboard, as he had planned. He himself would travel by land.

verses.latin: Cumque convenisset nos Assonem, assumpto eo, descendimus Mitylenen.
verses.english: When he met us in Assos, we took him aboard and went to Mitylene.

verses.latin: Et inde navigantes, sequenti die venimus contra Chium: et alia quidem applicuimus Samum, sequenti vero die venimus Miletum.
verses.english: We sailed from there and the next day arrived opposite Chios. The following day we put in at Samos, and the next day we arrived at Miletus.

verses.latin: Proposuerat enim Paulus transnavigare Ephesum, ne moraretur in Asia. Festinabat enim, si possibile sibi esset, diem Pentecostes observare Jerosolymis.
verses.english: Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus so that he would not have to spend time in Asia, because he was hurrying to be in Jerusalem, if possible, for the day of Pentecost.

verses.latin: A Mileto autem mittens, misit Ephesum, et convocavit majores natu ecclesiæ.
verses.english: From Miletus, he sent for the elders of the church in Ephesus.

verses.latin: Qui cum venissent ad eum, et convenissent, dixit eis: Vos scitis, a prima die qua ingressus sum in Asiam, qualiter per omne tempus vobiscum fuerim,
verses.english: When they came to him, he said, “You know how I lived among you the whole time from the first day I came to Asia,

verses.latin: serviens Domino cum omni humilitate, et lacrimis, et tentationibus, quæ mihi acciderunt ex insidiis Judæorum:
verses.english: “serving the Lord with all humility and with tears and trials, which befell me through the plots of the Jews.

verses.latin: quomodo nihil subtraxerim eorum quæ utilia sunt, quo minus annuntiarem, et docerem vos publice, et per domos,
verses.english: “How I did not shrink from declaring anything that was helpful for you, and teaching you publicly and from house to house,

verses.latin: testificans Judæis atque Græcis in Deum pœnitentiam, et fidem in Dominum Jesum.
verses.english: “testifying to both Jews and Greeks about repentance toward God and faith in our Lord Jesus.

verses.latin: Et nunc ecce vinctus ego spiritu, vado in Jerusalem: quæ in ea ventura sint mihi, ignorans:
verses.english: “And now, bound by the Spirit, I am going to Jerusalem, not knowing what will happen to me there,

verses.latin: nisi quod Spiritus Sanctus per civitates protestans mihi dicit, dicens quoniam vincula et tribulationes Hierosolymis me manent.
verses.english: “except that the Holy Spirit testifies to me in every city that imprisonment and afflictions await me.

verses.latin: Sed nihil horum vereor, nec facio animam meam pretiosiorem mihi, quam me, dummodo consummem cursum meum, et ministerium, quod accepi a Domino Jesu, testificari Evangelium gratiæ Dei.
verses.english: “But I do not consider my life of any account as dear to myself, in order that I may finish my course and the ministry which I received from the Lord Jesus, to testify to the gospel of the grace of God.

verses.latin: Et nunc ecce scio quia amplius faciem meam non videbitis vos omnes, per quos transivi prædicans regnum Dei.
verses.english: “And now, I know that you will no longer see my face, all of you among whom I went about preaching the kingdom.

verses.latin: Quapropter testor vos hodie, quia mundus sum a sanguine omnium.
verses.english: “Therefore, I testify to you this day that I am innocent of the blood of all of you.

verses.latin: Non enim subtraxi quo minus annuntiarem omnem consilium Dei vobis.
verses.english: “For I did not shrink from declaring to you the whole purpose of God.

verses.latin: Attendite vobis, et universo gregi, in quo vos Spiritus Sanctus posuit episcopos regere ecclesiam Dei, quam acquisivit sanguine suo.
verses.english: “Be on guard for yourselves and for all the flock, among which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers, to shepherd the church of God, which He purchased with His own blood.

verses.latin: Ego enim scio quoniam post discessum meum intrabunt lupi graves in vos, non parcentes gregi.
verses.english: “I know that after my departure, savage wolves will come in among you, not sparing the flock.

verses.latin: Et ex vobis ipsis exorientur viri, loquentes perversa, ut abducant discipulos post se.
verses.english: “And from among your own selves, men will arise, speaking perverse things to draw away the disciples after them.

verses.latin: Propter quod vigilate, memorantes quod per triennium nocte et die, non cessavi cum lacrimis monere unumquemque vestrum.
verses.english: “Therefore, be watchful, remembering that for three years I did not cease night and day to admonish each one with tears.

verses.latin: Et nunc commendo vos Deo, et verbo gratiæ ejus, qui potens est ædificare, et dare hereditatem in sanctis omnibus.
verses.english: “And now I commend you to God and to the word of His grace, who is able to build you up and to give you the inheritance among all those who are sanctified.

verses.latin: Argentum, et aurum, vel vestem nullius concupivi.
verses.english: “I coveted no one's silver or gold or clothes.

verses.latin: Vos ipsi scitis quoniam ad ea quæ mihi opus erant, et his qui mecum sunt, ministraverunt manus istæ.
verses.english: “You yourselves know that these hands ministered to my necessities and to those who were with me.

verses.latin: Omnia ostendi vobis, quoniam sic laborantes oportet suscipere infirmos, et meminisse verbi Domini Jesu, quoniam ipse dixit: Beatius est dare quam accipere.
verses.english: “In everything I showed you that by working hard in this manner you must help the weak and remember the words of the Lord Jesus, that He Himself said, ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’ ”

verses.latin: Et cum hæc dixisset, positis genibus suis, cum omnibus illis oravit.
verses.english: When he had said these things, he knelt down and prayed with them all.

verses.latin: Magnus autem fletus factus est omnium: et procumbentes super collum Pauli, osculabantur eum,
verses.english: And they all wept a great deal, and falling on Paul’s neck, they kissed him,

verses.latin: dolentes maxime in verbo, quod diceret, quod amplius faciem ejus non essent visuri. Et deducebant eum in navem.
verses.english: being especially grieved by the word which he had spoken, that they would not see his face again. And they accompanied him to the ship.

verses.latin: Postquam ergo evasi, factum est, profecti sumus. Et directa cursu venimus in Coo, et sequenti in Rhodum, inde in Pataram.
verses.english: After we escaped, we set sail. We sailed straight to Cos, and on the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.

verses.latin: Et cum invenissemus navem transcurrentem in Phenicem, ascendentes navigavimus.
verses.english: We found a ship sailing to Phoenicia, and we boarded and set sail.

verses.latin: Cum apparuissemus autem Cypro, relinquentes eam ad sinistram, navigavimus in Syriam: et applicuimus Tyrum, illic enim navis expositura erat sarcinam.
verses.english: We sighted Cyprus, leaving it to the left, and sailed to Syria. We landed at Tyre because the ship was going to unload its cargo there.

verses.latin: Invenientes autem discipulos, mansimus ibi diebus septem: qui Paulo dicebant per Spiritum ne ascenderet Hierosolymam.
verses.english: Finding the disciples, we stayed there for seven days. Through the Holy Spirit, they warned Paul not to go up to Jerusalem.

verses.latin: His autem expletis, egressi sumus, et procebamus iter: omnes cum uxoribus et filiis deducentes nos foras civitatem: et, positis genibus in litore, oravimus.
verses.english: When our time there was up, we set out and continued on our way. They all, with their wives and children, escorted us out of the city. Kneeling down on the beach, we prayed.

verses.latin: Et cum valefecissemus invicem, ascendimus navem: illi autem redierunt in sua.
verses.english: After saying goodbye to each other, we went aboard the ship, and they returned home.

verses.latin: Nos vero cursum navigantes, a Tyro pervenimus Ptolemaida: et salutantes fratres, mansimus die unum apud illos.
verses.english: We continued our voyage and sailed from Tyre to Ptolemais, where we greeted the brothers and stayed with them for a day.

verses.latin: Et cum essemus, die sequenti, profecti, venimus Caesaream. Et intrantes in domum Philippi evangelistæ, qui erat unus de septem, mansimus apud eum.
verses.english: The next day we set out and came to Caesarea. We entered the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the Seven, and stayed with him.

verses.latin: Huic autem erant filiæ quatuor virgines, prophetantes.
verses.english: He had four unmarried daughters who prophesied.

verses.latin: Mane autem cum moraremur ibi multis diebus, descendit quidam a Judæa, propheta, nomine Agabus.
verses.english: As we were staying there for many days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.

verses.latin: Et cum venisset ad nos, accepit zonam Pauli, et, alligans sibi pedes et manus, dixit: Hæc dicit Spiritus Sanctus: Virum, cujus est zona hæc, sic alligabunt in Jerusalem Judæi, et tradent in manus gentium.
verses.english: He came to us and took Paul’s belt, and binding his own feet and hands, he said, “Thus says the Holy Spirit: ‘The man whose belt this is, the Jews will bind in Jerusalem and deliver into the hands of the Gentiles.’”

verses.latin: Quod cum audissemus, rogabamus et nos, et qui ibi erant, ut non ascenderet Hierosolymam.
verses.english: When we heard this, we and the others there begged Paul not to go up to Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Tunc respondit Paulus: Quid facitis plorantes, et affligentes cor meum? Ego enim paratus sum, non solum alligari, sed et mori in Jerusalem pro nomine Domini Jesu.
verses.english: Then Paul answered, “Why are you weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be bound, but also to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.”

verses.latin: Cum autem eum persuadere non possemus, quievimus, dicentes: Domini voluntas fiat.
verses.english: When he would not be persuaded, we ceased and said, “The will of the Lord be done.”

verses.latin: Post hos autem dies, praeparati, ascendebamus Hierosolymam.
verses.english: After these days, we got ready and went up to Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Venerunt autem et de discipulis a Caesarea nobiscum, adducentes secum apud quem hospitaremur, Mnasonem quendam Cyprium, veterem discipulum.
verses.english: Some of the disciples from Caesarea came with us, bringing us to the house of Mnason of Cyprus, an early disciple, where we were to stay.

verses.latin: Cum venissemus autem Hierosolymam, susceperunt nos fratres libenter.
verses.english: When we arrived in Jerusalem, the brothers received us gladly.

verses.latin: Sequenti autem die, introibat Paulus nobiscum ad Jacobum: omnesque seniores convenerunt.
verses.english: The next day Paul went in with us to James, and all the elders were present.

verses.latin: Quos cum salutasset, narrabat per singula, quæ fecisset Deus in gentibus per ministerium ipsius.
verses.english: After greeting them, he related one by one the things that God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.

verses.latin: At illi, ut audierunt, magnificabant Deum, dixeruntque ei: Vides, frater, quot millia sunt in Judæis, qui crediderunt: et omnes æmulatores sunt legis.
verses.english: When they heard it, they glorified God. And they said to him, “You see, brother, how many thousands there are among the Jews of those who have believed. They are all zealous for the law.

verses.latin: De te autem audierunt, quia discessionem doces a Moyse eorum, dicens non debere circumcidere filios, neque in consuetudinibus ambulare.
verses.english: And they have been told about you, that you teach all the Jews who are among the Gentiles to forsake Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children or walk according to the customs.

verses.latin: Quid ergo est? Oportet ergo congregari multitudinem: audient enim te esse venturum.
verses.english: What then is to be done? They will certainly hear that you have come.

verses.latin: Hoc ergo fac quod dicimus tibi. Sunt nobis viri quatuor, votum habentes super se.
verses.english: Do therefore what we tell you. We have four men who have taken a vow.

verses.latin: Hos adsume, et sanctifica te cum illis: et impende in illis, ut radant caput: et cognoscent omnes, quia quæ de te audiunt, falsa sunt: sed ambulas et tu custodiens legem.
verses.english: Take these men and purify yourself along with them, and pay their expenses, so that they may shave their heads. And all will know that there is nothing in what they have been told about you, but that you yourself also walk orderly, keeping the law.

verses.latin: De his autem, quæ de gentibus crediderunt, nos misimus, judicantes servare eos, ab idolis, et fornicatione, et suffocato, et sanguine.
verses.english: But as for the Gentiles who have believed, we have sent a letter with our decision that they should abstain from what has been sacrificed to idols, and from blood, and from what has been strangled, and from sexual immorality.”

verses.latin: Tunc Paulus, adsumptis viris, sequenti die, purificatus cum illis, intravit in templum, annuntians expletionem dierum purificationis, donec offerretur pro unoquoque eorum oblatio.
verses.english: Then Paul took the men, and the next day he purified himself with them and went into the temple, announcing the fulfillment of the days of purification, until the offering was offered for each one of them.

verses.latin: Ut autem septem dies essent inchoati, qui a Judæis erant de Asia, videntes eum in templo, concitaverunt omnem populum, et injecerunt ei manus,
verses.english: When the seven days were almost completed, the Jews from Asia, seeing him in the temple, stirred up the whole crowd and laid hands on him,

verses.latin: clamantes: Viri Israëlitae, adjuvate: hic est homo, qui adversus populum, et legem, et locum hunc, omnes ubique docens: insuper et gentiles induxit in templum, et contaminavit locum sanctum.
verses.english: crying out, “Men of Israel, help! This is the man who is teaching everyone everywhere against the people and the law and this place. Moreover, he also brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place.”

verses.latin: (Viderant enim Trophimum Ephesium in civitate cum ipso, quem existimaverunt quoniam in templum induxisset Paulus.)
verses.english: For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city, and they supposed that Paul had brought him into the temple.

verses.latin: Commota est autem civitas tota: et factus est concursus populi, et adprehendentes Paulum, trahebant eum extra templum: et statim clausæ sunt ostiæ.
verses.english: The whole city was stirred up, and the people rushed together. They seized Paul and dragged him out of the temple, and immediately the doors were shut.

verses.latin: Quærentes eum interficere, nuntiatum est tribuno cohortis, quia tota civitas Hierosolymorum conmotam fuisset.
verses.english: As they were seeking to kill him, the report came to the tribune of the cohort that all Jerusalem was in confusion.

verses.latin: Qui, statim adsumptis militibus, et centurionibus, cucurrit ad eos. Illi autem, ut viderunt tribunum et milites, cessaverunt percutere Paulum.
verses.english: He at once took soldiers and centurions and ran down to them. When they saw the tribune and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.

verses.latin: Tunc accedens tribunus, adprehendit eum, et jussit vinci duabus cathenis: et interrogabat quis esset, et quid fecisset.
verses.english: Then the tribune came up and arrested him, and ordered him to be bound with two chains. He inquired who he was and what he had done.

verses.latin: Alii autem aliud clamabant in turba. Et cum non posset certum cognoscere propter tumultum, jussit eum duci in castra.
verses.english: Some in the crowd were shouting one thing, some another. And as he could not learn the facts because of the uproar, he ordered him to be brought into the barracks.

verses.latin: Cum autem factus esset ad gradus, factum est ut portaretur a militibus propter vim turbæ.
verses.english: When he came to the steps, he was carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the crowd,

verses.latin: sequebatur enim multitudo populi, clamans: Tolle eum.
verses.english: for the mob of the people followed, crying out, “Away with him!”

verses.latin: Et cum intrare debebat Paulus in castra, dicit ad tribunum: Si licet mihi, loqui tibi?
verses.english: As Paul was about to be brought into the barracks, he said to the tribune, “May I say something to you?”

verses.latin: Qui ait: Græce nosti?
verses.english: And he replied, “Do you know Greek?

verses.latin: Nonne tu es Aegyptius, qui ante hos dies tumultum concitasti, et eduxisti in desertum quatuor millia virorum sicariorum?
verses.english: Are you not the Egyptian, who before these days stirred up a revolt and led out into the desert the four thousand men of the Assassins?”

verses.latin: Dixit autem Paulus: Ego homo sum Judæus, de Tarso Ciliciæ civis non ignotiæ: rogo autem te, permitte mihi loqui ad populum.
verses.english: Paul said, “I am a Jew, from Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of no mean city. I beg you, permit me to speak to the people.”

verses.latin: Viri fratres et patres, audite quae nunc ad vos loquor pro defensione mea.
verses.english: Men, brothers, and fathers, hear now my defense!

verses.latin: Cum autem audissent quod lingua Hebraea loqueretur ad eos, magis parati erant audire,
verses.english: They were even more ready to listen when they heard Paul speaking Hebrew.

verses.latin: et ait: Ego sum vir Judaeus, natus Tarso Ciliciae, nutritus autem in ista civitate, ad pedes Gamaliel, eruditus secundum veritatem legis patrum, zelotes Dei, sicut omnes vos estis hodie:
verses.english: Then Paul said: “I am a Jew, born in Tarsus of Cilicia, but raised in this city. I studied at the feet of Gamaliel, and I was taught in accordance with the law of our fathers. I was full of zeal for God, as all of you are today.

verses.latin: qui persecutus sum hanc viam usque ad mortem, alligans et tradens in custodias viros ac mulieres:
verses.english: I persecuted the followers of this new way, even to the point of death. I imprisoned men and women.

verses.latin: sicut et princeps sacerdotum mihi testimonium reddit, et omnis senatus: a quibus et epistolas accipiens ad fratres, Damascum pergebam, ut et eos qui illic erant vinctos adducerem in Jerusalem, ut punirentur.
verses.english: The high priest and the entire council can testify to this. After receiving letters to the brothers, I was on my way to Damascus to bring back the prisoners who were there to Jerusalem to be punished.

verses.latin: Factum est autem, eunte me et appropinquante Damasco, media die repente de caelo circumfulsit me lux magna:
verses.english: As I was on my way and approaching Damascus, around noon a bright light suddenly flashed around me from the universe:

verses.latin: et cadens in terram audivi vocem dicentem mihi: Saule, Saule, quid me persequeris?
verses.english: I fell to the ground and heard a voice say to me: ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?’

verses.latin: Ego autem respondi: Quis es, Domine? Dixitque ad me: Ego sum Jesus Nazarenus, quem tu persequeris.
verses.english: I answered, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ And He said to me, ‘I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom you are persecuting.’

verses.latin: Et qui erant mecum, viderunt quidem lumen, sed vocem non audierunt ejus, qui mecum loquebatur.
verses.english: Those who were with me saw the light, but they did not hear the voice of the one who was speaking to me.

verses.latin: Et dixi: Quid faciam, Domine? Dominus autem dixit ad me: Surge, et vade Damascum: et ibi dicetur tibi de omnibus quae oportet te facere.
verses.english: I said, ‘What shall I do, Lord?’ The Lord replied, ‘Go to Damascus, and there you will be told all that you are appointed to do.’

verses.latin: Cum non viderem prae claritate lucis illius, adductus a manibus eorum qui mecum erant, veni Damascum.
verses.english: Since I could not see because of the brightness of the light, I was led by the hand by those who were with me, and I went to Damascus.

verses.latin: Ananias autem quidam, vir secundum legem, testimonium habens a cunctis habitantibus in ea,
verses.english: A man named Ananias, a devout observer of the Law, who was well respected by all the Jews living there,

verses.latin: veniens ad me, et assistens, dixit mihi: Saule frater, respice. Et ego hora illa respexi illum.
verses.english: came and stood by me, and said, ‘Brother Saul, regain your sight.’ And at that very moment I looked up at him.

verses.latin: Qui dixit: Deus patrum nostrorum praedestinavit te, ut cognosceres voluntatem ejus, et videres Justum, et audires vocem ex ore ejus:
verses.english: He said, ‘The God of our ancestors has appointed you to know His will, to see the Righteous One, and to hear the sound of His voice.

verses.latin: quia eris illi testis ad omnes homines eorum quae vidisti et audisti.
verses.english: For you will be his witness to all people of what you have seen and heard.

verses.latin: Et nunc quid moraris? Exsurge, et baptizare, et ablue peccata tua, invocans nomen ejus.
verses.english: And now, why delay? Get up, be baptized, and wash away your sins, calling on His name.’

verses.latin: Factum est autem mihi, revertenti in Jerusalem, et oranti in templo, factus sum in excessu mentis,
verses.english: It happened that when I returned to Jerusalem and was praying in the temple, I fell into a trance.

verses.latin: et vidi eum dicentem mihi: Festina, et exi cito de Jerusalem, quoniam non recipient testimonium tuum de me.
verses.english: I saw Him saying to me, ‘Hurry and get out of Jerusalem quickly, because they will not accept your testimony about me.’

verses.latin: Et ego dixi: Domine, ipsi sciunt quod ego eram in carceribus, persequens, et caedens per synagogas eos qui credebant in te:
verses.english: I said, ‘Lord, they themselves know that I imprisoned and beat those who believed in You in every synagogue.

verses.latin: et cum funderetur sanguis Stephani testis tui, ego eram assistens, et consentiens, et custodiebam vestimenta eorum qui eum occidebant.
verses.english: And when the blood of Your witness Stephen was being shed, I was there, agreeing with his execution, and guarding the clothes of those who were killing him.’

verses.latin: Et dixit ad me: Vade, quoniam ego in gentes longe mittam te.
verses.english: Then He said to me, ‘Go, because I will send you far away to the nations.’

verses.latin: Audiebant autem eum usque ad hanc vocem, et levaverunt vocem suam, dicentes: Tollite de terra hunc, talis enim non erat dignus vivere.
verses.english: They listened to him until he said this. Then they raised their voices and shouted, ‘Get rid of this man from the earth, for he is not worthy to live!’

verses.latin: Clamantes autem, et projicientes pallia, et jactantes pulverem in aera,
verses.english: As they were shouting and throwing off their cloaks and tossing dust into the air,

verses.latin: jussit tribunus introduci eum in castra, et praecipere flagellari eum, et quaereret propter quam causam clamabant sic adversum eum.
verses.english: the tribune ordered Paul to be brought into the fortress and commanded that he be examined by scourging, to learn the reason why they were shouting against him.

verses.latin: Cumque praecinctum eum funibus Paulus dixisset ad centurionem qui assistebat ei: Si hominem Romanum licet vobis flagellare?
verses.english: When they stretched him out for the whips, Paul said to the centurion standing by, ‘Is it legal for you to scourge a man who is a Roman citizen?’

verses.latin: Quod cum audisset centurio, accessit ad tribunum, dicens: Vide quid acturus sis: hic enim homo Romanus est.
verses.english: When the centurion heard this, he went to the tribune and told him, saying, ‘What are you about to do? For this man is a Roman citizen.’

verses.latin: Accedens autem tribunus, dixit ei: Dic mihi, si tu Romanus es? At ille dixit: Ego sum.
verses.english: The tribune approached Paul and asked, ‘Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?’ And Paul replied, ‘I am.’

verses.latin: Et respondit tribunus: Ego magna summa hanc civitatem accep, At Paulus dixit: Ego natus sum.
verses.english: The tribune answered, ‘I paid a large sum for this citizenship.’ Paul said, ‘But I was born a citizen.’

verses.latin: Protinus ergo discesserunt ab eo qui eum torquere debebant: tribunus quoque timuit, postquam comperit quia civis Romanus esset, et quia eum vinxerat.
verses.english: Then immediately those who were about to examine him withdrew. The tribune was also afraid because he had bound Paul, since he knew that he was a Roman citizen.

verses.latin: In crastinum volens scire plane a quo causam accusaverint eum Judaei, solvit eum, et jussit venire sacerdotes et omne concilium, et producens Paulum, statuit in eos.
verses.english: Wishing to know the real reason why the Jews were accusing him, the next day the tribune released Paul and ordered the chief priests and the entire Sanhedrin to assemble. Then he brought Paul down and placed him before them.

verses.latin: Paulus autem intuens oculos concilii, dixit: Viri fratres, ego omni conscientia bona conversatus sum ante Deum usque in hodiernum diem.
verses.english: Then Paul, looking at the council, said: "Brothers, I have lived before God with a clear conscience, even to this day."

verses.latin: Pontifex autem Ananias praecepit eis qui assistebant, percutere os eius.
verses.english: But the high priest Ananias commanded those who stood by to strike him on the mouth.

verses.latin: Tunc Paulus ad eum dixit: Percutiet te Deus, paries dealbate! Sedens tu judicas me secundum legem, et contra legem jubes me percuti?
verses.english: Then Paul said to him: "God will strike you, you whitewashed wall! Do you sit there judging me according to the law, and then order me to be struck in violation of the law?"

verses.latin: Astantes autem dixerunt: Sacerdotem Dei maledicis?
verses.english: Those who stood by said: "Do you revile God's high priest?"

verses.latin: Ait Paulus: Nesciebam, fratres, quia princeps est. Scriptum est enim: Principem populi tui non maledices.
verses.english: And Paul said: "I did not know, brothers, that he was the high priest. For it is written, ‘You shall not speak evil of the ruler of your people.’"

verses.latin: Paulus autem sciens quia una pars erat Sadducaeorum, altera autem Pharisaeorum, clamabat in concilio: Viri fratres, ego Pharisaeus sum, filius Pharisaeorum: de spe et resurrectione mortuorum ego judicor.
verses.english: But Paul, knowing that one part of them were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, cried out in the council: "Brothers, I am a Pharisee, the son of a Pharisee. I am being judged for the hope and the resurrection of the dead."

verses.latin: Et cum hoc dixisset, facta est dissensio inter Pharisaeos et Sadducaeos; et divisa est multitudo.
verses.english: And when he had said this, there arose a division between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the multitude was divided.

verses.latin: Sadducaei enim dicunt non esse resurrectionem, neque angelum, neque spiritum: Pharisaei autem utrumque confitentur.
verses.english: For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, nor angel, nor spirit, but the Pharisees confess both.

verses.latin: Factus est autem clamor magnus. Et surgentes scribae, qui erant ex parte Pharisaeorum, pugnabant dicentes: Nihil mali invenimus in hoc homine: quod si spiritus locutus est ei, aut angelus?
verses.english: Then a great cry arose, and the scribes of the Pharisees' party rose up, contending and saying: "We find no evil in this man. What if a spirit has spoken to him, or an angel?"

verses.latin: Cum autem facta esset magna dissensio, timens tribunus, ne divideretur Paulus ab eis, jussit milites descendere, et eum a medio eorum rapere, et in castra ducere.
verses.english: And when a great dissension arose, the tribune, fearing lest Paul should be torn to pieces by them, commanded the soldiers to go down and take him from among them and bring him into the fortress.

verses.latin: Sequenti autem nocte assistens ei Dominus, dixit: Confide: quomodo enim testificatus es de me in Jerusalem, sic oportet te et Romam testificari.
verses.english: And the following night, the Lord stood by him and said: "Be of good cheer; for as you have testified of me in Jerusalem, so must you bear witness also at Rome."

verses.latin: Facta autem die, conjurationem fecerunt Judaei, et devoverunt se dicentes, neque manducaturos, neque bibituros, donec interficerent Paulum.
verses.english: And when day came, the Jews formed a conspiracy and bound themselves under oath, saying that they would neither eat nor drink until they had killed Paul.

verses.latin: Erant autem plures quam quadraginta qui hanc conjurationem fecerant.
verses.english: There were more than forty who had formed this conspiracy.

verses.latin: Qui accesserunt ad principes sacerdotum et seniores, et dixerunt: Devoto devovimus nos nihil gustare, donec interficiamus Paulum.
verses.english: They went to the chief priests and the elders and said: "We have bound ourselves under a solemn oath to taste nothing until we have killed Paul."

verses.latin: Nunc ergo vos cum concilio, significate tribuno, ut illum cras producat ad vos, quasi aliquid amplius inquisituri de eo. Nos autem priusquam accedat, parati sumus ad interficiendum eum.
verses.english: So now you, with the council, give notice to the tribune so that he may bring him down to you tomorrow, as though you were going to examine his case more fully. And we are ready to kill him before he comes near."

verses.latin: Quod cum audisset filius sororis Pauli insidias, veniens et introiens in castra, nuntiavit Paulo.
verses.english: But when Paul's sister's son heard of their ambush, he went and entered the fortress and told Paul.

verses.latin: Vocato autem Paulus uno ex centurionibus, ait: Hunc adduc puerum ad tribunum: habet enim aliquid illi nuntiare.
verses.english: Then Paul called one of the centurions and said: "Take this young man to the tribune, for he has something to tell him."

verses.latin: Qui cum accepisset, ad tribunum duxit eum, et ait: Vinctus Paulus rogavit me, hunc juvenem ad te perducere, qui haberet aliquid tibi loqui.
verses.english: The centurion took him, and brought him to the tribune, and said: "Paul the prisoner called me and asked me to bring this young man to you, as he has something to say to you."

verses.latin: Tribunus autem adprehendens manum pueri, et secreto interrogabat: Quid est quod mihi debes nuntiare?
verses.english: The tribune took the young man by the hand and, taking him aside, asked him privately: "What is it that you have to tell me?"

verses.latin: Qui dixit: Judaei convenerunt, ut rogent te, quatenus cras Paulum producas in concilium, quasi aliquid de eo curaturi sunt.
verses.english: And he said: "The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down to the council tomorrow, as though they were going to inquire more fully about him.

verses.latin: Tu ergo ne credideris illis: insidiantur enim ei ex eis viri plus quam quadraginta, qui devoverunt se, non manducare, neque bibere, donec interficiant eum: et jam parati sunt, exspectantes promissum a te.
verses.english: So do not listen to them, for more than forty men from among them are lying in wait for him, who have bound themselves under oath neither to eat nor drink until they have killed him. And they are now ready, waiting for your promise."

verses.latin: Tribunus ergo dimisit puerum, praecipiens, ne cui enuntiaret haec, et dixit: Nemini enuntiaveris haec, quia tu mihi haec indicasti.
verses.english: Then the tribune dismissed the young man, charging him, "Tell no one that you have informed me of these things."

verses.latin: Vocatis autem duobus centurionibus, dixit: Parate milites ducentos, ut eant usque Caesaream, et equites septuaginta, et lancearios ducentos, hora tertia noctis.
verses.english: He then called two centurions and said: "Prepare two hundred soldiers to go to Caesarea, and seventy horsemen, and two hundred spearmen, at the third hour of the night."

verses.latin: Et jumenta praeparate, ut imponentes Paulum salvum deducant ad Felicem praesidem.
verses.english: Also, provide mounts so that they may set Paul on them and bring him safely to Felix the governor."

verses.latin: scribens epistulam, continens formam istam.
verses.english: And he wrote a letter, which read as follows:

verses.latin: Claudius Lysias optimo praesidi Felici salutem.
verses.english: "Claudius Lysias, to the most excellent governor Felix, greetings.

verses.latin: Hunc virum adprehensum a Judaeis, et interficiendum, cum cognovissem, quia Romanus est, cum exercitu superveni.
verses.english: This man was seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them. When I learned that he was a Roman citizen, I came upon them with the soldiers.

verses.latin: Volens scire causam, quam ob causam accusabant eum, detuli eum in concilium eorum.
verses.english: Desiring to know the cause why they accused him, I brought him down to their council.

verses.latin: Quem inveni accusari de quaestionibus legis eorum: nullum autem crimen dignum morte, aut vinculis habens.
verses.english: I found him to be accused over questions about their law, but as having no charge worthy of death or imprisonment.

verses.latin: Denuntiatus autem mihi de insidiis Judaeorum, statim misi ad te, denuntians et accusatoribus dicere adversus eum coram te. Vale.
verses.english: And when it was revealed to me that the Jews were planning an ambush for the man, I sent him to you without delay, and I also commanded his accusers to state their case before you. Farewell."

verses.latin: Milites igitur juxta praeceptum acceptum, Paulum assumpserunt, et duxerunt per noctem in Antipatridem.
verses.english: So the soldiers, as they were commanded, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris.

verses.latin: Hac autem die, equitibus tradentes Paulum, ut irent ad Felicem praesidem.
verses.english: On the next day they left the horsemen to go with him, and they returned to the fortress.

verses.latin: Qui cum venissent Caesaream, et tradidissent epistulam praesidi, praesentaverunt etiam Paulum illi.
verses.english: When they came to Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor, they also presented Paul to him.

verses.latin: Qui cum legisset, interrogavit eum de qua provincia esset: et cognoscens quia de Cilicia,
verses.english: And when he had read it, he asked him what province he was from. And when he learned that he was from Cilicia,

verses.latin: «Audiam te, inquit, cum accusatores tui venerint.» Et jussit eum custodiri in praetorio Herodis.
verses.english: "I will hear your case," he said, "when your accusers arrive." And he ordered him to be kept in Herod's praetorium.

verses.latin: Post dies autem quinque, descendit Ananias pontifex, cum senioribus, et cum Tertullo oratore, qui accusavit Paulum apud praesidem.
verses.english: Five days later, Ananias the high priest went to Caesarea, along with some of the elders, and with the orator Tertullus. They made accusations against Paul to the governor.

verses.latin: Vocato autem eo, coepit Tertullus accusare, dicens: Cum summa pace fruentes per te, et plurima corrigentur genti huic per tuam providentiam,
verses.english: After Paul was summoned, Tertullus began his accusation, saying: "Since we are experiencing much peace through your wise governance, and many reforms are being made for our people by your foresight,"

verses.latin: semper et ubique, optime Felix, gratias agnoscimus.
verses.english: “we always and in all places acknowledge this, most excellent Felix, with all gratitude.

verses.latin: Sed ne longius te morer, rogo audire nos in brevi, pro tua clementia.
verses.english: But, so as not to detain you, I ask that you hear us briefly, with your usual kindness.

verses.latin: Invenimus enim hunc hominem pestilens, et concitatem seditiones inter omnes Judaeos in universo orbe, et auctorem seditionis Nazaraeorum:
verses.english: “For we have found this man to be a pestilence, stirring up insurrections among all the Jews throughout the world, and a leader of the sect of the Nazarenes.

verses.latin: qui etiam templum voluit violare: quem et tenuimus.
verses.english: “He even tried to profane the Temple. We arrested him.

verses.latin: Aduenit autem Lysias tribunus, et cum magna violentia eripuit eum de manibus nostris,
verses.english: “But Lysias the tribune came and rescued him from our hands by using great force.

verses.latin: jubens accusatores ejus ad te venire: a quo potes, de omnibus istis, cognoscere.
verses.english: “He ordered his accusers to come to you. From him, you can learn about all these things.

verses.latin: Intentati sunt autem et Judaei, asserentes eadem esse.
verses.english: “The Jews also joined in the accusation, asserting that these things were so.”

verses.latin: Respondit autem Paulus, nutu praesidis, dicere: Sciens te per multos annos judicem esse genti huic, fidenter pro me ipso satisfacio.
verses.english: Then Paul, by a nod from the governor, began his defense: “Knowing that you have been a judge over this nation for many years, I confidently make my defense.

verses.latin: Potest enim cognoscere, quod non plus quam duodecim dies sunt, ex quo ascendi Hierosolymam adorare:
verses.english: “For you can ascertain that it is no more than twelve days since I went up to Jerusalem to worship.

verses.latin: et neque in templo invenerunt me disputantem cum aliquo, aut facientem concursum turbæ, neque in synagogis, neque in urbe:
verses.english: “And they did not find me disputing with anyone in the Temple, or causing a riot among the people, nor in the synagogues, nor in the city.

verses.latin: neque probare possunt ea, quæ nunc mihi objiciunt.
verses.english: “And they cannot prove the things they now accuse me of.

verses.latin: Confiteor autem hoc tibi, quod secundum viam, quam dicunt hæreticam, ita deservio Deo patrum meorum, credens omnibus quæ in lege et prophetis scripta sunt:
verses.english: “But I confess this to you: that I worship the God of my ancestors in the way they call a heresy, believing everything laid down in the Law and the Prophets.

verses.latin: spem habens in Deo, quam et isti ipsi exspectant, resurrectionem futuram justorum et iniquorum.
verses.english: “I have hope in God, which they themselves also await, that there will be a resurrection of the just and the unjust.

verses.latin: Et in hoc ipso studio habeo me ipsum sine offendiculo conscientiam habere ad Deum, et ad homines semper.
verses.english: “And so, I always strive to keep my conscience clear before God and men.

verses.latin: Post annos autem plures, adlatus sum ferre eleemosynas et oblationes in gentem meam:
verses.english: “Now, after many years, I came to bring alms and offerings for my nation.

verses.latin: in quibus inventi sum, a Judæis, in templo purgatus, non cum turba, neque cum tumultu.
verses.english: “While I was in these activities, some Jews from Asia found me in the Temple. I was purified and not with a crowd or in an uproar.

verses.latin: Qui debuerant stare coram te, et accusare, si quid haberent adversum me.
verses.english: “They should have been here before you to make accusations, if they had any against me.

verses.latin: Aut hi ipsi dicant, si quid invenerunt in me iniquitatis, cum starem in concilio,
verses.english: “Or let these men here themselves state what wrong they found when I stood before the council,

verses.latin: nisi de una hac voce, qua clamavi stans inter eos: Quia de resurrectione mortuorum ego judicor hodie a vobis.
verses.english: “unless it was for this one statement I cried out while standing among them: 'It is concerning the resurrection of the dead that I am being judged before you today.'

verses.latin: Felix autem, auditis his, distulit eos, dicens: Cum cognovero diligentius, quæ ad vos pertinent, tunc audiam.
verses.english: Felix, having heard these things, postponed the hearing, saying: “When I have examined the case more carefully, I will decide it.

verses.latin: Præcepitque centurioni custodiri Paulum, et habere remissionem, et neminem prohibere familiares ejus ministrare ei, vel accedere ad eum.
verses.english: He ordered the centurion to keep Paul in custody, but to allow him some freedom and not to prevent any of his friends from ministering to or visiting him.

verses.latin: Post dies autem aliquot, veniens Felix cum Drusilla uxore sua, quæ erat Judæa, vocavit Paulum, et audivit eum de fide, quæ est in Christo Jesu.
verses.english: After some days, Felix came with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish, and sent for Paul and heard him speak about the faith that is in Christ Jesus.

verses.latin: Disputante autem illo de justitia, et continentia, et de judicio futuro, tremefactus Felix, respondit: Vade modo, et, cum tempus accepero, vocabo te:
verses.english: And as Paul discussed righteousness, self-control, and the coming judgment, Felix was alarmed and said: "Go away for the present, and when I have an opportunity, I will send for you."

verses.latin: simul sperans quod pecunia a Paulo daretur ei, propter quod et sæpius illum vocabit, et loquebatur cum eo.
verses.english: At the same time, he hoped that money would be given to him by Paul, so he often sent for him and talked with him.

verses.latin: Biennio autem completo, accepit Felix succedente Porcio Festo: volens autem gratiam Judæis facere, reliquit Paulum vinctum.
verses.english: When two years had passed, Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus. Wishing to do the Jews a favor, Felix left Paul in prison.

verses.latin: Festus igitur cum in provinciam venisset, post triduum ascendit Jerosolymam a Caesarea.
verses.english: After Festus arrived in the province, he went up to Jerusalem from Caesarea after three days.

verses.latin: Intimarunt autem ei principes sacerdotum, et primi Judaeorum adversus Paulum, et deprecabantur eum,
verses.english: The high priests and the Jewish leaders went to him and informed Festus about Paul, begging him,

verses.latin: postulantes gratiam contra eum, ut mitteret eum in Jerosolymam: insidias enim parabat ei, ut eum interimirent in via.
verses.english: asking a favor against him, that he send him to Jerusalem. They were plotting to kill him along the way.

verses.latin: Festus autem respondit, Paulum in Caesarea custodiri, et se cito esse venturum.
verses.english: Festus replied that Paul was being kept under guard in Caesarea and that he himself would be returning quickly.

verses.latin: Qui ergo in vobis, inquit, potentes sunt, descendentes simul cum eo, si quid est in viro hoc malum, accusent eum.
verses.english: “Therefore,” he said, “let the men among you who are powerful go down with me and accuse him if there is anything wrong with the man.”

verses.latin: Moratus autem inter eos non amplius quam octo aut decem dies, descendens Caesaream, et altera die sedit pro tribunali, et jussit Paulum adduci.
verses.english: After spending eight or ten days among them, he went down to Caesarea. The next day he sat on the tribunal and ordered Paul to be brought in.

verses.latin: Qui cum apparuisset, circumsteterunt eum Judaei, qui de Jerosolymis descenderant, multas graves causas objicientes, quas non poterant probare,
verses.english: When he appeared, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him, bringing many serious charges which they couldn't prove,

verses.latin: Paulo se defendente, quod neque in legem Judaeorum, neque in templum, neque in Caesarem quidquam peccasset.
verses.english: while Paul defended himself, saying that he had committed no offense against the Jewish Law, nor against the Temple, nor against Caesar.

verses.latin: Festus autem, Gratiam Judaeis volens praestare, respondens Paulo, ait: Visne Jerosolymam ascendens, ibi de his judicari me praesente?
verses.english: Festus, wishing to do a favor for the Jews, answered Paul: “Are you willing to go up to Jerusalem and be judged there before me in these matters?”

verses.latin: Dixit autem Paulus: Ad tribunal Caesaris sto, ubi me oportet judicari: Judaeis non feci injuriam, sicut et tu optime scis.
verses.english: Paul said: “I am standing at Caesar’s tribunal, where I ought to be judged. I have done no wrong to the Jews, as you yourself well know.”

verses.latin: Si enim injuriam feci, aut morte dignum quid gessi, non recuso mori: si vero nihil est eorum quae isti accusant me, nemo potest me illis donare: Caesarem appello.
verses.english: “If I have done wrong, or have committed anything worthy of death, I don’t refuse to die. But if there is nothing in what these men accuse me of, no one can give me over to them. I appeal to Caesar.”

verses.latin: Tunc Festus, conlocutus cum consilio, respondit: Caesarem appellasti: ad Caesarem ibis.
verses.english: Then Festus, after conferring with the council, answered: “You have appealed to Caesar; to Caesar you shall go.”

verses.latin: Postquam autem transacti sunt dies aliquotiens, Agrippa rex et Bernice descenderunt Caesaream, et salutaverunt Festum.
verses.english: After some days had passed, King Agrippa and Bernice came down to Caesarea and greeted Festus.

verses.latin: Cumque moram fecissent ibi multos dies, Festus Paulo exposuit ea quae erant de eo, dicens: Vir quidam est relictus a Felice vinctus,
verses.english: After they had spent many days there, Festus explained Paul’s case to the king, saying: “There is a certain man left prisoner by Felix,

verses.latin: de quo, cum essem Jerosolymis, obtinuerunt adversum eum principes sacerdotum et seniores Judaeorum, postulantes damnationem.
verses.english: about whom, when I was in Jerusalem, the high priests and the elders of the Jews asked for a judgment, demanding condemnation.

verses.latin: Quibus respondi, quia non est consuetudo Romanorum hominem aliquem donare, prius quam is qui accusatur, praesentes habeat accusatores, et locum defendendi accipiat pro injuriis.
verses.english: I answered them that it is not the custom of the Romans to hand over any man before the accused has his accusers present, and he is allowed to defend himself against the charges.

verses.latin: Cum ergo venissent huc, sine mora, altera die sedens pro tribunali, jussi virum adduci.
verses.english: So when they came here, without delay, I sat on the tribunal the next day and ordered the man to be brought in.

verses.latin: Circumstantibus autem accusatoribus, nullam causam attulerunt, de qua ego hunc suspicabar malum agere:
verses.english: When the accusers stood around, they brought no charge of any wrongdoing that I suspected of him.

verses.latin: sed quaestiones quasdam de sua superstitione habebant adversus eum, et de quodam Jesu defuncto, quem dicebat Paulus vivere.
verses.english: But they had some questions about their own superstition against him, and about a certain Jesus who had died, whom Paul said was alive.

verses.latin: Haeitans ego circa istam quaestionem, dicebam si vellet ire Jerosolymam, et ibi de his judicari.
verses.english: Because I was uncertain about this question, I asked if he wanted to go to Jerusalem and be judged there concerning these matters.

verses.latin: Paulo autem appellante, ut conservaretur ad sententiam Augusti, jussi eum custodiri, donec mitterem eum ad Caesarem.
verses.english: But when Paul appealed to be kept for the judgment of the Emperor, I ordered him to be kept in custody until I could send him to Caesar.”

verses.latin: Agrippa autem ad Festum ait: Vellem et ipse audire hominem. Cras, inquit, audies eum.
verses.english: Then Agrippa said to Festus: “I would also like to hear the man.” “Tomorrow,” he said, “you will hear him.”

verses.latin: Altera itaque die cum venisset Agrippa et Bernice cum magna pompa, et introissent in auditorium cum tribunis et viris principibus civitatis, et jussu Festi, adductus est Paulus.
verses.english: The next day, when Agrippa and Bernice arrived with great pomp, and entered the audience hall with the tribunes and the leading men of the city, at the command of Festus, Paul was brought in.

verses.latin: Et ait Festus: Rex Agrippa, et universi qui nobiscum estis viri, videtis hunc, de quo omnis multitudo Judaeorum interpellavit me, Jerosolymis et hic, clamantes, quod non oportet eum vivere amplius.
verses.english: Festus said: “King Agrippa, and all of you here with us, you see this man, about whom the whole multitude of Jews has petitioned me, both in Jerusalem and here, crying out that he shouldn’t live any longer.

verses.latin: Mihi autem visum est nihil egisse mortis: ipso autem hoc appellante Augustum, judicavi eum mittendum.
verses.english: But to me it seemed that he had done nothing deserving of death. But because he appealed to the Emperor, I have decided to send him.”

verses.latin: De quo certo non habeo quid scribam domino: propter quod produxi eum ad vos, et maxime coram te, rex Agrippa: ut, examinatione facta, habeam quid scribam.
verses.english: “I don’t have anything certain to write to the Lord about him. Therefore I have brought him before you, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that after the investigation, I may have something to write.

verses.latin: Sine causa enim mihi videtur mittere vinctum, et causas ejus non significare.
verses.english: “For it seems to me unreasonable to send a prisoner and not to show the charges against him.”

verses.latin: Paulus, manu sua scribens, respondit: Rex Agrippa, de his, de quibus me accusas, ego me beatum existimo, quod coram te hodie me debeam defendere,
verses.english: Paul, writing with his own hand, said: “King Agrippa, I consider myself blessed that I have to defend myself today before you concerning all of the things of which you accuse me,

verses.latin: maxime cum sis peritus in omnibus, et Judaeorum consuetudinibus, et quaestionibus: propter quod rogo te patienter me audias.
verses.english: especially because you are well acquainted with all the customs and the controversies among the Jews. I therefore beg you to listen to me patiently.

verses.latin: Nam et vita mea a juventute, quae fuit ab initio in gente mea, in Jerosolymis, notam habent omnes Judaei,
verses.english: For my life from my youth, which was from the beginning among my nation and in Jerusalem, is well known to all the Jews,

verses.latin: qui praesciunt me ab initio, si velint testimonium perhibere: quoniam secundum severissimam sectam nostrae religionis, vixi pharisaeus.
verses.english: who know me from the beginning, if they wish to bear witness, because I lived according to the strictest sect of our religion, as a Pharisee.

verses.latin: Et nunc in spem promissionis, quae facta est a Deo ad patres nostros, sto judicatus:
verses.english: And now I stand here to be judged for the hope of the promise which was made by God to our fathers,

verses.latin: in quam duodecim tribus, in continuis deservientes, sperant devenire. De qua spe accusor a Judaeis, rex.
verses.english: the hope of which the twelve tribes, continuously serving, hope to attain. Concerning this hope I am accused by the Jews, O king.

verses.latin: Quare putatis incredibile, si Deus mortuos resuscitavit?
verses.english: Why do you consider it unbelievable that God raises the dead?

verses.latin: Ego quidem putavi me oportere multa contraria facere nomini Jesu Nazareni:
verses.english: I truly thought that I ought to do many things against the name of Jesus of Nazareth:

verses.latin: quod et feci Jerosolymis: et multos sanctorum ego in carcerem inclusi, a principibus sacerdotum potestate accepta: et cum interficerentur, dabam sententiam.
verses.english: and I did this in Jerusalem. I imprisoned many of the saints, having received authority from the chief priests. And when they were being put to death, I cast my vote against them.

verses.latin: Et per omnes synagogas frequenter puniens eos, coëgebam blasphemare: et amplius insaniens in eos, persequebar usque in exteriores civitates.
verses.english: And punishing them often in every synagogue, I forced them to blaspheme. And I was extremely enraged at them, even persecuting them to distant cities.

verses.latin: In quibus dum proficiscerer Damascum, cum potestate et permissu principum sacerdotum,
verses.english: In which I was traveling to Damascus, with the authority and permission of the chief priests,

verses.latin: media die vidi in via, rex, de caelo supra splendorem solis circumfulgentem me lumen et eos qui mecum erant.
verses.english: at midday, O king, I saw on the road a light from the sky, brighter than the sun, shining around me and those who were with me.
