verses.latin: Omnibus autem nos prostratis in terram, audivi vocem loquentem mihi, hebraica lingua: Saule, Saule, quid me persequeris? Durum tibi est contra stimulum calcitrare.
verses.english: But when we all had fallen to the ground, I heard a voice speaking to me in the Hebrew language: “Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It is hard for you to kick against the goad.”

verses.latin: Ego autem dixi: Quis es, Domine? Dominus autem dixit: Ego sum Jesus, quem tu persequeris.
verses.english: And I said, “Who are you, Lord?” And the Lord said, “I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting.

verses.latin: Sed exsurge, et sta super pedes tuos: ad hoc enim apparui tibi, ut constituam te ministrum, et testem eorum quae vidisti, et eorum in quibus apparebo tibi,
verses.english: But rise up and stand on your feet; for I have appeared to you for this purpose, that I may appoint you as a minister and a witness of those things which you have seen and of those things in which I will appear to you,

verses.latin: eripiens te de plebe, et gentibus, ad quas nunc mitto te,
verses.english: delivering you from the people and from the Gentiles, to whom I now send you,

verses.latin: ut aperias oculos eorum, ut convertantur a tenebris ad lucem, et a potestate Satanæ ad Deum, ut accipiant remissionem peccatorum, et sortem inter sanctos per fidem, quae est in me.
verses.english: to open their eyes, that they may turn from darkness to light and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins and an inheritance among those who are sanctified by faith in me.”

verses.latin: Unde rex Agrippa, non fui incredulus caelesti visionis:
verses.english: Wherefore, O king Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision,

verses.latin: sed his, qui Damasci sunt, primum, et Jerosolymis, et in omnem terram Judaeae, et gentibus adnuntiabam pœnitentiam, et conversionem ad Deum, cum digna pœnitentiæ opera facerent.
verses.english: but proclaimed to those of Damascus first, and in Jerusalem, and throughout all the country of Judea, and also to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, performing works worthy of repentance.

verses.latin: Propter hanc causam me Judaei, cum essem in templo, conati sunt, me interficere.
verses.english: For this reason the Jews, when I was in the temple, tried to kill me.

verses.latin: Auxiliatus autem Dei, usque in diem hanc sto, testificans a minimo usque ad maximum, nihil extra dicens quam ea quae prophetæ sunt locuti, et Moyses facturus.
verses.english: Having therefore obtained help from God, I stand to this day, testifying both to small and great, saying nothing except those things which the prophets and Moses said would come to pass:

verses.latin: scilicet Christum passurum, et primus ex resurrectione mortuorum, lucem adnuntiaturum plebi et gentibus.
verses.english: that Christ should suffer, that He should be the first to rise from the dead, and that He would proclaim light to the people and to the Gentiles.”

verses.latin: Hæc loquente eo ad se, ait Festus magna voce: Dementaris, Paule: multa te litteræ ad insaniam convertunt.
verses.english: As he was saying these things in his defense, Festus said with a loud voice, “Paul, you are out of your mind! Much learning is driving you to madness.”

verses.latin: At ille: Non desipío, inquit, optime Feste, sed veritatis et sobrietatis verba profero.
verses.english: But Paul said, “I am not out of my mind, most excellent Festus, but I am speaking the words of truth and soberness.

verses.latin: Scit enim de his rex, ad quem et fiducialiter loquor. Latere enim eum nihil horum arbitror: neque enim in angulo gestum est aliquid.
verses.english: For the king knows about these things, to whom I also speak with confidence. For I am persuaded that none of these things has escaped his notice, for this was not done in a corner.

verses.latin: Credis, rex Agrippa, prophetis? Scio quod credis.
verses.english: King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know that you believe.”

verses.latin: Agrippa autem ad Paulum: In brevi, inquit, persuades me Christianum fieri.
verses.english: Then Agrippa said to Paul, “In a short time you persuade me to become a Christian.”

verses.latin: Et Paulus: Optarem, inquit, apud Deum, et in brevi, et in magno, non tantum te, sed et omnes qui me audiant hodie, fieri tales qualis et ego sum, exceptis vinculis istis.
verses.english: And Paul said, “I would to God that not only you, but also all those who hear me today, might become such as I am, except for these chains.”

verses.latin: Et cum hæc dixisset, surrexit rex, et praeses, et Bernice, et qui una considebant cum eis.
verses.english: When he had said these things, the king, the governor, Bernice, and those who were sitting with them rose up;

verses.latin: Et cum recessissent, loquebantur ad invicem, dicentes: Quia nihil morte, aut vinculorum dignum, facit hic homo.
verses.english: and when they had withdrawn, they talked with one another, saying, “This man is doing nothing worthy of death or chains.”

verses.latin: Agrippa autem Festo ait: Dimitti poterat hic homo, si non appellasset Cæsarem.
verses.english: Then Agrippa said to Festus, “This man could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar.”

verses.latin: Cum autem statutum esset, ut navigaremus in Italiam, tradebant Paulum et alios vinctos centurioni, nomine Julio, de cohorte Augusti.
verses.english: When it was decided that we would sail for Italy, Paul and some other prisoners were handed over to a centurion named Julius, who was from the Augustan cohort.

verses.latin: Ascendentesque navem Adramyttinam, quae velabat circa loca Asiae, veximus, existentes nobiscum Aristarchus Macedo, Thessalonicensis.
verses.english: We boarded a ship from Adramyttium, which was about to sail to ports along the coast of Asia. Aristarchus of Thessalonica, a Macedonian, was with us.

verses.latin: Altera autem die applicuimus Sidonem: et, Julius Paulum tractans, cum humanitate concessit amicis, ut curam illi gererent.
verses.english: The next day, we put in at Sidon. Julius treated Paul kindly and allowed him to visit his friends and receive their care.

verses.latin: Et inde procurrentes, subnavigavimus Cyprum, propterea quod venti contrarii erant.
verses.english: We set sail from there and sailed along the coast of Cyprus, because the winds were against us.

verses.latin: Mareque per Ciliciam et Pamphyliam currentes, venimus Myram Lyciam.
verses.english: We sailed through the sea off Cilicia and Pamphylia, and arrived at Myra in Lycia.

verses.latin: Et ibi inveniens centurio navem Alexandrinam navigantem in Italiam, imposuit nos in eam.
verses.english: There the centurion found a ship from Alexandria that was sailing for Italy, and he put us aboard it.

verses.latin: Et cum multis diebus tarde navigantes, et vix adplicantes contra Gnidum, prohibente nos vento, navigavimus sub Creta juxta Salmonem:
verses.english: After sailing slowly for many days, we arrived with difficulty off Cnidus. Because the wind was against us, we sailed along the coast of Crete, near Salmone.

verses.latin: et cum difficulter praeterveheremur, venimus in locum quemdam, qui vocatur Boniportus, cui juxta erat civitas Lasea.
verses.english: We struggled to sail along it and came to a place called Fair Havens, near the city of Lasea.

verses.latin: Et cum multo tempore insumptum esset, et iam navigatio periculo esset, quia et ieiunium iam præterierat, monebat Paulus
verses.english: Since much time had passed and the voyage was now dangerous, because the Fast was already over, Paul warned them,

verses.latin: dicens eis: Viri, video quoniam cum injuria et magno damno, non solum navigii et sarcinarum, sed etiam animarum nostrarum, futura est navigatio.
verses.english: “Men, I see that this voyage will be disastrous and cause great damage, not only to the ship and the cargo, but also to our lives.”

verses.latin: Centurio autem gubernatori et nauclero magis credebat, quam his quae a Paulo dicebantur.
verses.english: But the centurion was more persuaded by the helmsman and the ship’s captain than by what Paul said.

verses.latin: Et cum aptus non esset portus ad hiemandum, plures censuerunt inde solverent, si quo modo possent pervenire Phenicem hiemare, portum Cretae, respicientem ad Africam et ad Chorum.
verses.english: Because the harbor wasn’t suitable for wintering, most of them decided to sail on from there, hoping to reach Phoenix, a harbor in Crete facing southwest and northwest, to winter there.

verses.latin: Aspirante autem austro, aestimantes propositum se consecuturos, levantes navem, legebant Cretam juxta.
verses.english: When a gentle south wind began to blow, thinking that they had obtained their purpose, they weighed anchor and sailed along Crete.

verses.latin: Non post multum vero misit se contra illam ventus typhonicus, qui vocatur Euroaquilo.
verses.english: But soon a hurricane-force wind, called the northeaster, struck the ship.

verses.latin: Et cum rapere vellet navem, et non posset ventis contraria, dedimus vela, et ferebamur.
verses.english: The ship was caught and could not head into the wind, so we gave way to it and were driven along.

verses.latin: Incurrentes autem in quandam insulam, quae vocatur Cauda, potuimus vix obtinere naviculam: quae cum sublevata esset, adjutoriis utebantur, subcingentes navem, timorem habentes ne inciderent in Syrtim, summovere vela, et sic ferebantur.
verses.english: Running under the lee of a small island called Cauda, we were barely able to get the ship’s boat under control. After hoisting it aboard, they used ropes to rig the ship, and fearing that they would run aground on the Syrtis, they lowered the sails and let the ship be driven along.

verses.latin: Cum autem violentius iactaretur nos tempestas, postera die iaculabantur: tertia autem die suis manibus armamenta navis projecerunt.
verses.english: The next day, as we were being violently tossed by the storm, they began to jettison cargo. On the third day, they threw the ship’s gear overboard with their own hands.

verses.latin: Neque autem solis, neque siderum apparitio, per dies plurimos, illuxit: et tempestas magna urgebatur, jam ablata erat spes omnis salutis nobis.
verses.english: When neither sun nor stars appeared for many days, and the storm continued raging, all hope of our being saved was at last gone.

verses.latin: Et cum abstinentia multorum esset, tunc stans Paulus in medio eorum, ait: Oportuit quidem, o viri, obedientes mihi fuisse, et non tollere a Creta, lucrati hac injuria et jactura.
verses.english: Since they had been without food for a long time, Paul stood up among them and said, “Men, you should have taken my advice not to set sail from Crete and have avoided this damage and loss.

verses.latin: Et nunc suadeo vobis bonam spem: salus enim animarum vestrarum, et neminis ex vobis peribit.
verses.english: “But now I urge you to keep up your courage, because not one of you will be lost; only the ship will be lost.

verses.latin: Adstitit enim mihi hac nocte angelus Dei, cujus ego sum, et cui deservio,
verses.english: “For last night an angel of the God to whom I belong and whom I serve stood beside me

verses.latin: dicens: Ne timeas, Paule: Caesari te oportet assistere: et ecce donavit tibi Deus omnes, qui sunt tecum.
verses.english: and said, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul. You must stand trial before Caesar. And God has graciously given you the lives of all who sail with you.’

verses.latin: Propter quod boni animi estote, viri: credo enim Deo, quod sic futurum est quemadmodum dictum est mihi.
verses.english: So keep up your courage, men, for I have faith in God that it will happen just as he told me.

verses.latin: Sed oportet nos in quandam insulam incurrere.
verses.english: “We must run aground on some island.”

verses.latin: Jacta autem nocte, facta est, et, ut putabamus, appropinquabamus alicui terrae: et jactantes ancoras de puppi, optabamus diem fieri.
verses.english: About midnight the sailors sensed that they were approaching land. They took soundings and found that the water was twenty fathoms deep. A short time later they took soundings again and found it was fifteen fathoms. Fearing that we would run aground on the rocks, they dropped four anchors from the stern and prayed for daylight.

verses.latin: Cum autem quaererent fugere de navi, et misissent scapham in mare, quasi volentes de navi exire:
verses.english: In an attempt to escape from the ship, the sailors let the lifeboat down into the sea, pretending they were going to let go anchors from the bow.

verses.latin: dixit Paulus centurioni et militibus: Nisi hi manserint in navi, vos salvi fieri non potestis.
verses.english: Then Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, “Unless these men stay with the ship, you cannot be saved.”

verses.latin: Tunc absciderunt milites funes scaphæ, et passi sunt eam cadere.
verses.english: Then the soldiers cut the ropes that held the lifeboat and let it fall away.

verses.latin: Dum autem dies incipiebat fieri, rogabat Paulus omnes accipere cibum, dicens: Quartadecima die, hodie, exspectantes jejuni, perstantes, nihil accipientes.
verses.english: When daylight began to appear, Paul urged them all to take some food, saying, “For the past fourteen days you have been in constant suspense, without food, eating nothing.

verses.latin: Propter quod rogo vos accipere cibum: hoc enim pro salute vestra est: quoniam nullus vestrum pilus capitis peribit.
verses.english: “Therefore I urge you to take some food. You need it for your survival, for not a hair of your head will be lost.”

verses.latin: Et cum hoc dixisset, accepto pane, gratias egit Deo in conspectu omnium: et, cum fregisset, coepit manducare.
verses.english: After he said this, he took some bread and gave thanks to God in front of them all. Then he broke it and began to eat.

verses.latin: Recreati autem omnes, et ipsi acceperunt cibum.
verses.english: They were all encouraged and ate some food themselves.

verses.latin: Eramus autem omnes in navi, animæ ducentae septuaginta sex.
verses.english: Altogether there were 276 of us on board.

verses.latin: Saturati vero cibo, alleviaverunt navem, jactantes frumentum in mare.
verses.english: When they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship by throwing the grain into the sea.

verses.latin: Cum autem lux facta esset, terram ignoraverunt: sinum vero considerabant, habentem littus, in quem cogitabant, si possent, expellere navem.
verses.english: When day came, they did not recognize the land, but they saw a bay with a sandy beach, where they planned to run the ship ashore if they could.

verses.latin: Et cum ancoras sustulissent, committebant se mari, simul laxantes gubernacula navium: et, levantes cor, in velum venti ferebantur.
verses.english: Cutting loose the anchors, they put out to sea, and at the same time loosened the ropes that held the rudders. They hoisted the foresail to the wind and sailed toward the beach.

verses.latin: Incurrentes autem in locum maris, bidui, impellebant navem: et inciderunt in locum, ubi mare frangitur, et navis illisa, puppis quidem solvebatur a violentia.
verses.english: But striking a reef, the ship ran aground, and the bow stuck fast and remained immovable, but the stern was being broken to pieces by the surf.

verses.latin: Militum autem consilium fuit, ut custodias vinctos interficerent, ne quis enatans effugeret.
verses.english: The soldiers planned to kill the prisoners, lest any of them should swim away and escape.

verses.latin: Centurio autem, volens salvare Paulum, prohibuit eos a consilio: jussitque eos, qui possent natare, primum se mittere, et exire et ad terram tendere.
verses.english: But the centurion, wishing to save Paul, kept them from carrying out their plan. He ordered those who could swim to jump overboard first and get to land,

verses.latin: reliquos autem, alios quidem in tabulis, alios vero super ea quae erant de navi. Et sic factum est, ut salvi fierent omnes ad terram.
verses.english: and the rest on planks or on pieces of the ship. And so it was that all were brought safely to land.

verses.latin: Et cum evasissemus, tunc cognovimus quia Melita insula vocatur.
verses.english: After we survived the shipwreck, we learned that the island was called Melita.

verses.latin: Barbari vero praestabant non modicam humanitatem nobis.
verses.english: The local people treated us with uncommon kindness.

verses.latin: Accendentes enim ignem, universos nos receperunt propter imbrem, qui inerat, et propter frigus.
verses.english: They lit a fire and welcomed us all because of the rain and the cold.

verses.latin: Paulus autem, collecta sarmentorum multitudine, et imponens super ignem, vipera de calore, cum processisset, adhaesit manui ejus.
verses.english: Paul gathered a bundle of brushwood and put it on the fire. A viper, driven out by the heat, fastened itself on his hand.

verses.latin: Cum viderent autem barbari bestiam pendentem de manu ejus, dicebant ad invicem: Utique homicida est homo iste, qui, cum evaserit de mari, ultio eum non sinit vivere.
verses.english: When the local people saw the snake hanging from his hand, they said to one another, “Surely this man is a murderer! Though he escaped from the sea, justice has not allowed him to live.”

verses.latin: Ipse vero, excutiens bestiam in ignem, nihil mali passus est.
verses.english: Paul, however, shook the snake into the fire and suffered no harm.

verses.latin: At illi existimabant eum in futurum inflaturum, et subito casurum et moriturum. Diu autem illis sperantibus, et videntibus nihil mali ei accidisse, convertentes se, dicebant eum esse deum.
verses.english: They were expecting him to swell up or suddenly fall down dead. But after they had waited a long time and saw that nothing happened to him, they changed their minds and said that he was a god.

verses.latin: In locis autem illis erant praedia principes insulae, nomine Publius, qui suscipiens nos, triduo amantissime suscepit.
verses.english: Near that place were the lands of the chief man of the island, whose name was Publius. He welcomed us and showed us generous hospitality for three days.

verses.latin: Contigit autem patrem Publii febribus et dysenteria vexari: ad quem Paulus introiens, et orans, et imponens ei manus, curavit eum.
verses.english: It happened that Publius' father was sick with a fever and dysentery. Paul went in to see him, and after praying and laying his hands on him, he healed him.

verses.latin: Quo facto, qui in insula erant ceteri, qui habebant infirmitates, accedebant, et curabantur.
verses.english: After this happened, the rest of the people on the island who had diseases also came and were cured.

verses.latin: Qui et honoribus multis honorati sunt nos, et, cum navigaremus, imposuerunt quae necessaria erant.
verses.english: They honored us with many honors, and when we set sail, they put on board whatever we needed.

verses.latin: Post menses autem tres, navigavimus in nave Alexandrina, quae in insula hiemaverat, cui erat insigne Castorum.
verses.english: After three months, we set sail in an Alexandrian ship that had wintered on the island. It had the figurehead of the twin gods, Castor and Pollux.

verses.latin: Et cum venissemus Syracusam, mansimus ibi triduo.
verses.english: We put in at Syracuse and stayed there for three days.

verses.latin: Inde circumcurrentes, venimus Rhegium. Et post unum diem, flante austro, venimus Puteolos.
verses.english: From there we sailed along and arrived at Rhegium. The next day the south wind came up, and we reached Puteoli.

verses.latin: In quo fratres inventi, rogati sumus manere apud eos dies septem: et sic venimus Romam.
verses.english: There we found some brothers and sisters and were invited to stay with them for seven days. And so we came to Rome.

verses.latin: Et inde, cum audissemus, processerunt a nobis fratres obviam nobis usque Appii Foro et Trium Tabernarum: quos cum vidisset Paulus, gratias agens Deo, fiduciam accepit.
verses.english: The brothers and sisters there heard that we were coming and came as far as the Market of Appius and Three Taverns to meet us. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and took courage.

verses.latin: Postquam autem venimus Romam, concessum est Paulo manere cum sibi, cum custodiente milite.
verses.english: When we reached Rome, Paul was allowed to live by himself, with the soldier who was guarding him.

verses.latin: Factum est autem post triduum, convocatis a se principibus Judaeorum, ait illis: Ego, fratres, nihil contra plebem faciens, aut morem paternum, vinctus de Jerosolymis traditus sum in manus Romanorum,
verses.english: After three days, Paul called together the leaders of the Jews. When they had come together, he said to them, “Brothers, although I had done nothing against our people or the customs of our ancestors, I was arrested in Jerusalem and handed over to the Romans.

verses.latin: qui, cum causam meam examinassent, voluerunt dimittere, eo quod nulla esset causa mortis in me.
verses.english: The Romans, after examining me, wanted to release me, because there was no reason for the death penalty in my case.

verses.latin: Contradicentibus autem Judaeis, coactus sum appellare Caesarem: non quasi gentem meam habeam aliquid accusans.
verses.english: But when the Jews objected, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar—not that I had anything to accuse my nation of.

verses.latin: Propter hanc igitur causam rogavi vos videre et loqui. Propter spem enim Israel, vinculis his circumdatus sum.
verses.english: For this reason, therefore, I have asked to see you and speak with you. For it is because of the hope of Israel that I am bound with this chain.”

verses.latin: At illi dixerunt ad eum: Nos neque litteras de te accepimus a Judaea, neque venit aliquis fratrum nuntians, aut loquens de te aliquid mali.
verses.english: They replied, “We have neither received any letters from Judea concerning you, nor has any of the brothers come here to report or speak any evil about you.

verses.latin: Rogamus autem a te audire, quae sentis: nam de hac secta notum est nobis quia ubique ei contradicitur.
verses.english: But we want to hear from you what you think, for we know that this sect is spoken against everywhere.”

verses.latin: Constituerunt autem ei diem, et venerunt ad eum in hospitium plures, quibus exponebat testificans regnum Dei, suadensque eis de Jesu, a lege Moysi et prophetis, a mane usque ad vesperam.
verses.english: So they arranged a day with him, and they came to him at his lodging in great numbers. He was explaining things to them, and he was testifying about the kingdom of God. From morning until evening, he was trying to convince them about Jesus, using the Law of Moses and the Prophets.

verses.latin: Et quidam credebant quae dicebantur, quidam vero non credebant.
verses.english: Some were convinced by what he said, but others disbelieved.

verses.latin: Non consentientes autem invicem, abierunt, dicente Paulo hoc verbum: Quia recte Spiritus Sanctus locutus est per Isaiam prophetam ad patres vestros, dicens:
verses.english: They disagreed among themselves and began to leave, after Paul had made this final statement: “The Holy Spirit spoke rightly to your ancestors through the prophet Isaiah, saying,

verses.latin: Vade ad populum istum, et dic ad eos: Auditu audietis, et non intelligetis; et videntes videbitis, et non videbitis.
verses.english: ‘Go to this people and say: “You will keep on hearing, but will never understand; you will keep on seeing, but will never perceive.

verses.latin: Incrassatum est enim cor populi hujus, et auribus graviter audierunt, et oculos suos clauserunt: ne forte videant oculis, et auribus audiant, et corde intelligant, et convertantur, et sanem eos.
verses.english: For the heart of this people has grown dull, and their ears are hard of hearing, and they have closed their eyes, so that they might not see with their eyes and hear with their ears and understand with their heart and turn, and I would heal them.’

verses.latin: Notum igitur sit vobis, quia gentibus missa est haec salus Dei, et ipsi audient.
verses.english: Therefore let it be known to you that this salvation of God has been sent to the Gentiles, and they will listen!”

verses.latin: Et cum haec dixisset, Judaeis discedentibus, magnam habuit quaestionem inter se.
verses.english: Paul spent two whole years in his own rented house, and he welcomed all who visited him,

verses.latin: praedicans regnum Dei, et docens quae sunt de Domino Jesu Christo, cum omni fiducia, sine prohibitione.
verses.english: proclaiming the kingdom of God and teaching about the Lord Jesus Christ with all boldness and without hindrance.
